thread.title: NAB becomes the first big four banks to sign on to ASX mFunds
thread.title_full: NAB becomes the first big four banks to sign on to ASX mFunds | afr.com

author: Matthew Smith
title: NAB becomes the first big four banks to sign on to ASX mFunds
text:
National Australia Bank is the first of the big four banks to sign up to mFunds. Louise Kennerley by Matthew Smith National Australia Bank is the first of the big four banks to sign up to mFunds, the ASX-operated exchange for unlisted managed funds.
NAB will include its investment products on mFund, as well as plug in nabtrade, its online equities trading platform. The agreement with NAB was described as a "significant milestone" by Marcus Christoe, ASX senior manager, funds and investment products.
To date, the banks have chosen to not participate in the managed funds exchange service, which streamlines the application and settlement process for investors to who want to buy and sell units in unlisted funds.
The ASX platform, which launched a year ago, effectively disintermediates financial advisors who have traditionally earned commissions by selling managed funds to their clients using technology platforms such as wraps and master trusts owned by the banks.
"I think the providers signing up to mFunds see it as a complement to their current business whether that be through financial advisors, ETFs, LICs and the like," Mr Christoe said.
While the industry participation in mFunds has been strong – there are 35 funds managers offering 120 funds through the nFunds service – transactions by retail investors is understood to have remained weak. The ASX will release the first data relating to mFunds transactions in November.
The addition of mFunds on the share trading platforms of the remaining three banks would likely bolster retail investors' participation in the fledgling managed funds transaction service, Mr Christoe said.
Discount brokerage firms including Bell Direct, CMC Markets, Baillieu Holst, Burrell Stockbroking and Pershing Securities, all offer access to the service through their respective platforms.
